name: 郭若妤
objective:
Data is everywhere. As the physical and digital worlds have become intertwined, more and more design decisions are expected to be supported by data analytics. Hence, this course aims to build your data literacy skills as a designer. The course will begin by introducing the need for personalized products and services to create a better user experience. This concerns not only the cognitive but also affective aspects. The insights obtained from the data can then be translated to determine product/service/system requirements. Students will spend the majority of the class time on research-oriented projects.
Upon completing this course, you will be able to:
1. Distinguish the difference between mass production and personalization 
2. Gain a better understanding of how data science can be incorporated into the design process 
3. Describe the characteristics and forms of data generated by different sources such as humans, machines, or environments 
4. Apply suitable tools/software to interpreT small- or large-scale dataset
5. Understand the key principles in the ethical use of data in the design process
schedule:
Week	Topics
1	Course objective, structure, syllabus, and grading
2	Introduction: Why design with data	
3	The diversity of data for digital and physical products	
4	Individual presentation: Case studies in ambient intelligence	
5	PART I: Getting data (Tools and methods for data collection)	
6	Discussion: The size and quality of a dataset	
7	University holiday 
8	Interim report submission: Research questions	
9	PART II: Turning data into understanding	
10	Discussion: Analytical tools and statistical methods	
11	Discussion: Eye tracking technique 	
12	Ethical use of data, privacy and security
13	YODEX young designers' exhibition
14	Emotion detection model
15	Risk prediction model
16	Discussion: Data visualization insights
17	Discussion: Reflecting on the design framework	
18	Final report submission
scorePolicy:
Attitude: Punctuality & Initiative (10%), Independence (10%)
Research project capability: Execution & Analysis (15%), Innovation (15%)
Final report: 50%
materials:
King, R., Churchill, E. F., & Tan, C. (2017). Designing with data: Improving the user experience with A/B testing. O'Reilly Media, Inc.
Sauro, J., & Lewis, J. R. (2016). Quantifying the user experience: Practical statistics for user research. Morgan Kaufmann.
Holmqvist, K., Nyström, M., Andersson, R., Dewhurst, R., Jarodzka, H., & Van de Weijer, J. (2011). Eye tracking: A comprehensive guide to methods and measures. OUP Oxford.
